title: Loyalty Program Perks - Best Method of Collecting Data
question_text:
A large cruise line operates many different sailings from many different home ports to many different destinations around the world.
Executives at the cruise line are considering making changes to their customer loyalty program.
Of course, they want to keep customers who are already part of the loyalty program happy, so they are interested in in learning more about what benefits these individuals find most advantageous. To do so, they are planning a survey that asks customers to rank the importance of various perks of the loyalty program.
Which of the following describes the best way to collect the data?

choices.text: Randomly select a few of the cruise line's ships that will be sailing during a certain month. Then, provide surveys to each individual who is currently enrolled in the loyalty program and sailing on one of the selected ships.

For each of the cruise line's ships, randomly select three sailings that are scheduled during the upcoming year. Then randomly select individuals who are on each of these sailings and provide each of these individuals with the survey.
Provide the survey to every individual sailing on one of the cruise line's ships during a randomly determined period of one month.

Send the survey by email to each individual currently enrolled in the customer loyalty program. If an individual does not respond, follow up the email with a paper survey addressed to the individual's home.
Place surveys in various travel-related magazines and ask that the surveys be returned to a given address.

solution:
When conducting a survey, it is important that the sample accurately represent the population of interest - in this case, members of the cruise line's loyalty program.

By attempting to contact every individual enrolled in the program, by email or by regular mail, the cruise line can most accurately gather the opinions of all members of the loyalty program regardless of when they cruise, from which home ports, and to which destinations.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect. This choice makes use of a cluster sample and does limit the sample to individuals from the population of interest. However, the month of the sailing could be a confounding variable. For example, if the month selected was during the summer, then the survey may be more likely to reach loyalty program members who are traveling with children while on summer vacation. The results may not accurately represent the population of all members of the loyalty program.

Choice 'B' is incorrect. This choice makes use of a stratified random sample. However, it does not limit the final sample to individuals who are part of the population of interest - those in the loyalty program. By randomly choosing individuals from the selected sailings, they may in fact be choosing individuals who are not part of the loyalty program.

Choice 'C' is incorrect. While it appears that this method is atempting to conduct a census (for one month), by providing the survey to "every individual", this method does not limit the sample to those who are part of the population of interest. Therefore, the results of the survey cannot accurately be applied to members of the loyalty program. Additionally, the use of responses for only one month may confound the results of the survey as described above.

Choice 'E' is incorrect. This choice makes use of a voluntary response sample in which the survey is made widely available but individuals must choose themselves to become part of the sample by filling out and returning the survey. Individuals who participate in voluntary response samples are likely to have strong opinions on certain issues and these opinions may not accurately represent the population of interest. Additionally, as described, this method of collecting data does not appear to limit the responses to those who are part of the loyalty program.
